text: Japan has a problem hundreds of
thousands of young men who locked
themselves away in their bedrooms
sometimes not leaving their homes for
decades
they're known as hikikomori people who
have completely withdrawn from society
[Music]
I've had angry at myself angry at
society like there was nothing I could
do it's a condition without a proper
medical diagnosis or a standard course
of treatment one-fifth master window
another time he passed my wife and the
broken ribs but there is something that
seems to be helping I echo is a rental
sister she and Atsuko are part of a
specialized group of women available for
hire who are getting paid to help
Japan's most reclusive young men get out
of their bedrooms and back into society
[Music]
away from Tokyo's bright lights tall
buildings and busy junctions are the
people I've come here to meet Akiko Mori
at different stages of a complex
recovery the condition can affect both
men and women but most are young men
between 18 and 35 and this is not just a
handful of people it's estimated that
there are about 4 million people living
as a Keiko Mori in Japan but because
there can be a lot of shame associated
with having a hikikomori child many
families keep the conditioner secret and
struggle to get proper help that's where
the rental sisters come in the idea was
dreamed up by an organization called new
start and it seems to be working these
young women don't have any formal
medical qualifications but families pay
about a hundred thousand yen a month for
weekly hour-long visits that's just
under nine hundred dollars their job is
to try to coax their Keiko Mori out of
isolation and back into regular life
so what does it take to be a rental
sister and are they actually helping to
solve the problem Tiffany guar there is
no technique I don't pretend I just try
to connect with them on their level
Ayaka has been a rental sister for over
a decade for the last six months she's
been working with a recovering her Kiko
Mori in his late 20s called Kenta his
parents pay for Ayaka to visit him every
two weeks she took me along to one of
her sessions in the suburbs of Tokyo
Kenta has now managed to move out of
home but still can't hold down a job
ayuk who told me that it can sometimes
take between six months and two years to
build trust and start the recovery
process I was bullied at school because
people thought I had a high-pitched
voice and I was friends with all the
girls in my class
they'd say are you a boy or girl how did
you feel when you were Akiko Mori
and more clearly I was taking medicine I
was so unhappy I cried every day blaming
my parents I felt completely lost one
time I even violent I was basically
nocturnal I stay up all night playing
video games and they sleep during the
day until the late afternoon the reason
why people become Mikiko Morrie is
complex and not well understood
sometimes like kenta's case the social
withdrawal can be caused by bullying or
a traumatic event
it can also stem from depression too
much pressure from parents or just
failure to hold down a job or degree
every case is different how do you feel
like having a rental sister has changed
you but in thoroughly thought I enjoyed
seeing my rental sister very much as we
go out to eat and go out together and I
feel like she's put me it makes so much
difference to how I feel compared with
just being alone me up Ayaka told me
later that it's actually quite rare for
the client to have fun with the rental
sister and enjoy seeing them but she's
hoping that soon Kenta won't need her
anymore
Illinois America the time when I stopped
seeing I aqua will be I'll miss her if I
cannot see her but when they can was
properly what people misunderstand is
very tough on the weak I also echo what
kind of approach she takes when working
with young men like Kenta if I try to be
something fake the patients will realize
that being myself just the way I am
even if I'm a bit late or tired the
client will feel I it's okay to be like
that it will be difficult if you're not
patient or get disappointed if the
client will not respond to you you have
to remember that this is just a job but
for the families with Akiko Mori
children the condition can have a huge
impact
I met a father we'll call him mr. haruto
whose son became withdrawn as a teenager
and two decades later still barely
leaves his room I don't know how to
handle this it feels like there are no
options even after the boy's mother died
he didn't change so I don't foresee any
hopes for the future so why is your son
in his room I don't know the reason one
day he's not stopped going to school at
first you go out sometimes to buy comic
books and then he's just stopped going
out altogether we didn't know what to do
there are two or three times we had to
call the police because my son got
violent
once he smashed the window another time
he punched my wife and the broken ribs
knowing where to get treatment can be
hard especially if they Akiko Mori
refuses to leave his room to visit a
doctor mr. Udo decided that New Starts
rental sisters seemed worth a try I
thought perhaps they could talk to my
son because he was Korea that family
members couldn't do anything anymore an
experienced rental sister called Atsuko
started to visit today I will visit the
hikikomori his home so far I visited
about 10 or 15 times but he never comes
out here to do so I have to talk to him
through the door apparently that's quite
a common reaction in the early stages
even though the young man refuses to
talk to her she still writes him long
letters that she pushes underneath the
door I try not to make them feel like
someone's looking down on them or trying
to control them I'm not trying to be a
teacher but I try to interact with them
like an older sister or a neighbor
someone more casual who all is about
them and is there for them as a gentle
presence most to Kiko amore aren't
violent but Atsuko always has to be on
her guard for any unpredictable behavior
when I do my visit there are many people
who are current and don't come out of
the bedroom but some hikiko Molly got
upset or about him
when a stranger comes into the space one
time when I was speaking to a boy he
physically attacked me grabbing me by
the throat I was very scared I called
the police right away I didn't want to
go back there rental sisters like Atsuko
armed mental health counselors and don't
have any formal qualifications they get
some training from new start but that's
about it
their mission is to help the hikikomori
be okay with who they are and how they
feel and to make that work for them in a
real-world setting but they will bring
in doctors if they feel like they need
to
I wanted to find out more about the
Akiko Mori condition and why it's such a
phenomenon in Japan I got in touch with
the man who wrote the defining book on
the subject professor and psychologist
Tamaki Saito this condition is very very
common in here calmly in Japan there are
resident 10,000 homeless people instead
there are about 1 million equally I
think this is a Japanese style of social
exclusion
professor Saito thinks the problem is
far more widespread than government
numbers suggest and it's also becoming
an issue in other countries like the US
UK Italy and South Korea where young men
might feel an overwhelming pressure to
succeed financially many people think
about history that they are very lazy
and other people think about it come on
is a very dangerous and precondition of
a criminal but that's not true
statistically not true living
independently it seemed to be a key part
of the recovery process some Mikiko Mori
might feel like they're ready to leave
their bedrooms but they aren't quite
stable enough to reintegrate back into
society
and that's where the new start dormitory
comes in it's kind of a halfway house
for recovering a Keiko Maureen they pay
rent to live there and must do some
part-time work and charity volunteering
which is organized by new start they
have to give up their phones and are
only allowed to watch TV in the communal
sitting room no computer games allowed
over the past 18 years
New START has had about 2,000 people
live in the dormitory for more than a
year 80% of those have now reestablished
themselves independently
[Music]
one of those former residents is equal
who's now in his mid-30s his stint in
the Newstart dormitory completely turned
his life around
when I worried I was totally alone in my
room and just played video games or
watch TV overall I felt angry at myself
angry at the society I felt completely
hopeless like there was nothing I could
do I came to a new start because I
didn't want to stay at my parents house
I didn't think much about it I just
wanted to be away from my parents while
staying in the dormitory he had to do
some volunteering at the new start
offices and it was there that he met his
future wife by a code the rental sister
they began speaking everyday and she
convinced him to start some part-time
work as a rental brother what made you
fall in love with each other I had a
strong feeling of camaraderie
it was him as a rental brother we took a
walking trip together in the mountains
near Tokyo where we could just talk and
be ourselves after we got married the
staff and residents from New START held
a celebration for us I didn't propose to
her properly until then so they're at a
party in front of everybody I proposed
and asked her to please smile forever
next despite the difficulties in stigma
that had Kiko amore face Ayaka said that
living your life more slowly and
thoughtfully can also have many
positives I married someone who used to
be withdrawn so I want to say this out
loud people who have spent time being
withdrawn also have very good important
qualities okay so they don't want to
work but they often see Society in a
fair way and have a very gentle view of
women
the Akiko Mori condition is still not
well documented and the Japanese
government is trying to get a clearer
picture of the situation to date New
Starts rental sisters have helped about
3,000 people get out of their rooms and
back into society but many of Japan's
Akiko Maurice still remain isolated
[Music]
